709393f-a.text:
725-727 Sixth Avc., west side, south of, and adjoining the S.W. corner of west 24th Street, showing (No. 725) the Sixth Ave. "Playground". It is provided with a rifle range, many slot-machine games, and cheap recorded music, as a diversion for people with not too fine an appreciation of good entertainment. It is similar to many such places found in Coney Island.
December 24, 1936.
L. Sperr.

(1)

background.
December 24, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

vendor in the foreground.
December 24, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

September 7th,I940
P.L.Sperr,

709394f-b.text:
Sixth Avenue, south from W. 24th Street, showing the "El" structure and its 23rd Street station undergoing demolition. The 19 story office structure at the left (No. 71 W. 23rd Street) is owned and partially occupied by the Masons. On the opposite corner (S.E.) is a 6 story loft building standing on the former site of Booths Theatre. The low units on the west side of this thoroughfare, between 23rd and 24th streets are nondescript, though the corner building at 24th Street identifies itself as being formerly Koster & Bials. This sign is out into the cornice roofing and does not appear here. An additional sign does, bearing "The Corner". The Koster & Bials Concert Hall of the 1890's was located around the corner at 15 W. 23rd Street and this may have been an annex. Two doors to the south is a structure containing a penny arcade, "Playland". This, the writer believes is one of the last, if not the last, of many similar and popular venture.

February 19, 1939

F.L. Sperr

This sign is out into the cornice roofing and does not appear here. An additional sign does, bearing "The Corner". The Koster & Bials Concert Hall of the 1890's was located around the corner at 15 W. 23rd Street and this may have been an annex. F.L. Sperr

709396f-b.text:
Sixth Avenue, north from West 24th Street. showing a reclaimed thoroughfare. This has been brought about by the recent demolition of the old 'El' structure that formerly darkened this Avenue. In the left background appears the Greeley Square section with it's distinctive Hotel McAlpin. Dominating the skyline is the towering
Empire State Building.
March 29, 1939
P. L. Sperr
(2)
The same area from a point slihtly south of 24th Street. Note the cleared site at the N.E. corner of same. This is being used by subway contractors as
a storage base and tunnel entrance.
October 28, 1939
P. L. Sperr

709398f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, north from W. 24th Street, showing the "El" structure darkening the street, and in turn being overshadowed by the Empire State Building.

The photographer is viewing towards Herald Square where several large structures appear, prominent of which is the Hotel McAlpin.

At this date, the "El" is under demolition, the same has not advanced to this point. Buildings at the left are on the west side of this thoroughfare and are more or less nondescript.

Jan. 7, 1939
Views: 1-2

P. L. Sperr

The same as above, from another angle.

P. L. Sperr                                        March 24, 1939

711766f-a.text:
West 24th Street, east from Sixth Avenue, showing a perspective towards Madison Square and its eternal light, and the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. Bldgs. A corner of the Fifth Avenue Bldg. obscures a better view of the tower feature to same.

May 9, 1940

P.L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS

711765f-a.text:
24th Street, east from but not including Sixth Ave. Shown in the background is the Metropolitan Life Insurance Building and Tower.

July 14, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
